I'll start by saying that I don't have children and don't have contact with my family.  Not in a bad way, I'm just a deeply selfish person.  My wife and I would rather soend our money on holidays, games and cats than anything serious like bringing up a child.  What's the point of this surprisingly personal and seemingly irrelevant disclosure?  Well, despite my shortcomings as an adult human, I loved The Novelist.

The Novelist is a game that will mean something different to every person who plays it, depending on their point of view.  The way the game plays is that a small family have rented a house for the summer - the father sees it as an opportunity to work on his book, the wife sees it as a chance to rebuild their failing relationship and it is supposed to be a chance to address the problem the son has at school.  You play as a spirit that haunts the house and it is up to you to influence the father at the end of each day as to how to handle an event (or events) that will affect the family.  You do this by gathering information on each person's take on the event and coming to a conclusion as to how best to handle it.  Find every piece of information, and you will be allowed a compromise at the end of the day, meaning that one person will come away happy with the result, one placated and one potentially unhappy.

This is all simply done, and can be played as either a casual point and click style game of (admittedly limited) exploration, or as an stealth-lite game that has you trying to avoid the family seeing you, and thus becoming spooked and denying you the ability to come to a compromise with them.  Playing this way is actually quite engaging and adds a light air of tension added to by the lack of saves during the day, meaning you have to live with your decisions and mistakes.

Although I found myself drawn to the characters, it wasn't necessarily through their actual interactions.  If anything, that would be the weakest part of the game.  The characters' personalities are all explored very well through diaries and journals, but doesn't come across in the world of the game.  It can be argued that it adds to the otherworldly feel to the game, but I think a lot would be added by the characters showing more... well... character.

Anyway returning to my opening paragraph - I felt when I started the game that I would absolutely be on the father's side.  The game is called The Novelist, he is earning the money in the family and the house was rented to allow him to work on his book.  So, fine.  Cut and dried, let's get this book printed!  Well, no.  Reading the wife's personal thoughts and fears about how close to divorce they are without him realising was actually quite scary.

OK.  Let's focus on the relationship and put the book on the sidelines, the kid will be fine.  The outcome of my first decision showed that the child was disappointed and I could live with that.  What I couldn't live with, was seeing him devastated at the next outcome screen.  So, well done, game!  I felt bad and went about actually making decisions for the good of the family as a whole.

As I played, it actually took me back to a holiday where my own father had to take time to study through it, something I haven't thought about in years, and realised that the developer absolutely nailed the scenario.  I actually found myself sympathetic towards each member in the family.  I wasn't working towards some winning gamestate at the end, but toward a scenario that would make everything OK for them all.  I was drawn in completely.

I obviously had a deeply personal connection to the game, so would it stand up without that?  I don't see why not.  It is short enough that it can even make a nice talking point if you play with another person as well.

On the whole, it is easy to recommend this game - I won't deny that you need you need a degree of empathy and maturity to fully apreciate it, but that's no bad thing.

A pretty decent (albeit short) decision-based game. Only complaint is that the endings seem oddly incoherent with the gameplay. I literally forgot to compromise 50% of the time and still ended up with a pretty positive ending. Also, every single choice makes you super guilty no matter what you end up picking. Disappointing Tommy is the new Clementine will remember this.""

reviewText:
In the Novelist you play as a vauge, intangible, but somehow visible, entity that can somehow influence the decisions of people living in a secluded house. You must sneak around teh house examining letters, journals, and even combing through the memories of the inhabitants, then make a choice for one of them that will necesarily mean sacrificing the happiness of the others. It's an interesting idea that's realized well in purely mechanical terms. I'd slike to try a game using the same engine that tells a more interesting story. Unfortunately, the actual game is terrible due to being the poorly told story of a horrible clan of boring idiots.

The people in the house arbitrarily fixate on doing particular things, and then cannot be happy unless everyone else is forced to do that and only that. They'll decide to go camping, for example, and then they will talk of nothing else until ti's been decided. You can literally peer into their very soul and all you will find is them saying they want to go camping. To be sure, there's existential terror to that idscovery, but not the kind the creator intended.

If you really want to see a good idea squandered, maybe pick this up in a steep sale. Otherwise save your money.

This is a really nice and rather simple game. A family of three - Dan (the father), Linda (the mother) and Tommy (their son) - moves in to a house in the middle of the woods, but only for the summer. The reason for them doing that is so that Dan could get the chance of finding some new inspiration for his upcoming book, for Linda to give her art a new chance and for Tommy to be in a new environment.

Throughout the game, the player explores the house the family's living in and have to make decisions on whos wishes should be fulfilled... and then there's a chance of making a compromise with one more family member. The decisions felt like they really mattered, at least to me. Once Linda had to hike in the woods, by herself, and broke (I think) her ankle and had to make it back to the house, all by herself. That made me feeling bad for making that one decision.

I really do recommend this, even though it's somewhat short... but you could always play it several times to make some different decisions.

Recommend, with a catch.

I got this at a discount, I think 40% off, and if I had paid full price I might have leaned toward thumbs down. All in all, it's an okay game, but nothing I was too excited about. If the choices you made were played out more rather than just giving a brief summary I might have liked it better. As it was I found it difficult to connect to the characters I was trying to help.

If you can get it as a discount price, or if the price drops, it's worth a look. It is an interesting game to play, but nothing to write home about.
To be a good novelist you have to either neglect your wife or your kid. Awesome.\n\n10/10 would frustrate again!

I actually found myself sympathetic towards each member in the family.  I wasn't working towards some winning gamestate at the end, but toward a scenario that would make everything OK for them all.  I was drawn in completely.

I obviously had a deeply personal connection to the game, so would it stand up without that?  I don't see why not.  It is short enough that it can even make a nice talking point if you play with another person as well.

On the whole, it is easy to recommend this game - I won't deny that you need you need a degree of empathy and maturity to fully apreciate it, but that's no bad thing.

reviewText:
In the Novelist you play as a vauge, intangible, but somehow visible, entity that can somehow influence the decisions of people living in a secluded house. You must sneak around teh house examining letters, journals, and even combing through the memories of the inhabitants, then make a choice for one of them that will necesarily mean sacrificing the happiness of the others. It's an interesting idea that's realized well in purely mechanical terms. I'd slike to try a game using the same engine that tells a more interesting story. Unfortunately, the actual game is terrible due to being the poorly told story of a horrible clan of boring idiots.

The people in the house arbitrarily fixate on doing particular things, and then cannot be happy unless everyone else is forced to do that and only that. They'll decide to go camping, for example, and then they will talk of nothing else until ti's been decided. You can literally peer into their very soul and all you will find is them saying they want to go camping. To be sure, there's existential terror to that idscovery, but not the kind the creator intended.

If you really want to see a good idea squandered, maybe pick this up in a steep sale. Otherwise save your money.

This is a really nice and rather simple game. A family of three - Dan (the father), Linda (the mother) and Tommy (their son) - moves in to a house in the middle of the woods, but only for the summer. The reason for them doing that is so that Dan could get the chance of finding some new inspiration for his upcoming book, for Linda to give her art a new chance and for Tommy to be in a new environment.

Throughout the game, the player explores the house the family's living in and have to make decisions on whos wishes should be fulfilled... and then there's a chance of making a compromise with one more family member. The decisions felt like they really mattered, at least to me. Once Linda had to hike in the woods, by herself, and broke (I think) her ankle and had to make it back to the house, all by herself. That made me feeling bad for making that one decision.

I really do recommend this, even though it's somewhat short... but you could always play it several times to make some different decisions.

Cool idea... was waiting for something cool to happen... never did. I was very very bored. Maybe if the outcomes or memories had more creativity to them, because they lacked imagination. The music is very eery and it just didn't match the tone of the game. I commend them on the new approach to gameplay mechanics. I'd love to see this again in a sequel or a different game.

The art is great, and reminiscent of oil paintings (especially the scenery outside). The story is what drives the game, but I feel it has it's challenges. It seems as though the family never speaks to one another unless they're arguing, and more often  than not some of the choices could realistically have been done as well, if your character wasn't limited to 2 choices instead of 3.
That raises the question, who exactly do you play as? You may never know. Are you a ghost that helps this family specifically? Or anyone who lives in the house? Are you even real? There is a long string of questions that could have added more to the story had they been answered, but instead the mystery remains.

7/10

Story is not that interesting,not detailed,not exciting,and just my taste,it didnt touch me in an emotional way.
So I do not recommend.

reviewText: The game's a bit short, and therefore you should consider waiting for it go on sale. But it's a lovely story told in a unique and intriguing way, which makes you question the sacrifices different family members have to make.\n\nDefinitely worth a go.

This was a very thoughtful game. It reminded me a lot of the Choose-Your-Own-Adventure books I loved when I was young. When I ended with an okay ending, I really wanted to go back and redo the whole thing. However, the choices were so emotionally exhausting (at least for an indecisive person like me), that I think I'll need to take a long break from the game before I replay.

This is a game that I am going to give a very soft recommendation for, because while this game has plenty of faults, I still enjoyed playing through it and I think others would too.

At it's core, The Novelist is a game about interpersonal conflict and the moral and ethical struggles that comes with trying to balance the wants and needs of individuals in a family. Each chapter in the game presents the player with three desires, one for each member of the family, and you are asked to make a decision based on these desires. I personally enjoyed exploring the house to find all the clues to each family member and I also enjoyed going through their memories to learn more about the situation as well.

However there are several problems I have with The Novelist, the chief one being that the story in and of itself isn't that interesting. It's a typical story, Dad wants to work on his novel, Mom wants to save the marriage and get back into a profession she had to give up when the kid arrived, and the kid wants to play with Dad and is struggling in school and is bullied. We've all seen stories that use these elements elsewhere, and they used them a lot better there. Another issue I had was that the individual chapters didn't seem to be all that connected. Each chapter felt more like variations of the same 3 or 4 issues and the decisions made in the previous chapter seemed to have little influence in other chapters.

For those who don't want to spend all their time twitch" shooting everything that moves in the face

reviewText: Great story with lots of possible outcomes. Interesting to play a game that revolves around human being's emotional choices. Also lots of clever interaction design. The stroy is strong but is sometimes clunky, however, I did feel real emotion by the end.

Following the successes of games like Gone Home and Actual Sunlight, The Novelist is another one of those games that will make traditional gamers question whether or not it actually is a game. A huge fan of exploratory/narrative games, however, I did enjoy my 3-4 play-throughs of the game. It doesn't capture the voyeuristic feel quite as fully as Gone Home and doesn't have a story quite as deeply touching as Actual Sunlight; rather, The Novelist falls somewhere between the two as a somewhat memorable, very relatable, and surprisingly touching experience as a voyeur into regular family life. It's a decent game, and although it certainly isn't mind-blowing, it has enough to be worth a play or two.\n\nYou play as a spectre living in a house that the Kaplan family decides to move into for a summer. reviewText:
Another interesting indie game.

It is short -- about 1 1/2 hours per playthrough, but it lends itself to multiple playthroughs.

The game is about choice -- when there are three characters with three different goals (a husband with his career, a wife and her career, and a son with difficulties in school), what is the right choice to make? Often the answer is complex, and there is no right answer. Give up to much for your family, and you might end up resenting your family.

I recommend, if you are into the indie/story based plots, or interested in how choice can be done in video games. Compare the choices/outcomes in this game with Fallout, Mass Effect, and Walking Dead.
One of the best video game stories I've played in a while.  Highly recommended.
Amazing. Only word I can think of that describes this game. F*cking amazing.

As much as I hate to say, it has let me down a bit although I was not all disappointed. It still has some good things in the game.

The game length was terribly short. I finished the game at only close to 2 hours and buying this game at about $10 does not seem to be all that reasonable (That is the discounted price. The original was close to $20 in SGD) and the gameplay becomes repetitive: Find clues for each character's desires, make a decision, see the outcome and then repeat again. It gets more boring and despite attempts to make things slightly more exciting, it only gives way to 1 or 2 intense moments.

Despite that, the story line is extremely flexible. The story is right below, in the description. The rest of the story is pretty much in your own hands. Each decision will even make the character's thoughts or insights different and has the possibility of impacting the ending.

What it does good as well as that it is impossible to balance the time and sacrifice is a need. When you make a decision, you affect others in a bad way. It actually forces you to keep questioning if whatever the character is doing is so important and whether another event is more important than the other. You will find yourself spending time on one of them and yet all at the same time, forsaking relationships.

3.8/5 It's most unfortunate that the game's story cannot hold out the repetitiveness of the game and the length or it might have been better :/ Until the, get this game only at a discounted price. 75% discount would be better.

The idea is brilliant. A hypnotic, slow paced story about conflicting interests in a troubled relation. You get to choose their priorities and witness the fallout. It's most definitely not a game for kids. Though it lacks any kind of graphic detail, there's just no way kids can relate to this game. I did however find some objectionable aspects of the game. First of all, moving around the house is very, very slow. You can jump between light fixtures to speed things up, but having the simple option to move faster would make this game 200% better. Secondly, finding the items that tell the story can be frustratingly difficult at times. Thirdly, though the script is surprisingly complex, the characters are annoyingly self centered. For instance, Linda, the wife, does not seem to be working for the sake of taking care of little Tommy. She is economically dependent on Dan, the husband. Yet she cannot let him work to bring home the dough. If she had the option to be the breadwinner, this would be fine. But she does not and her scripted selfishness is impossible to mediate.

Very well done. I put some serious thought into the decisions I made in this game, weighing the possible repercussions. In the end I was really happy with the choices I made and I got a good hour and a half of gameplay. If you're looking to pass some time this is a great way to do it, and you may learn a little something about yourself :)

I really like this one! And the multiple choice solutions for each chapter (one resolution, one compromise) give it great replay value. I love being able to sneak around the house searching for clues - possessing the lights is a neat feature. The clues themselves are really interesting glimpses into the lives of the fictional Kaplans. I totally sympathized with all of them and I wanted things to work out for the best for each one of them - too bad I could only do my best to help Dan maintain balance between his work, his marriage, and his son! Definitely recommend for those who like story-type investigative games. People who prefer action titles might not like it at all. It was perfect for me!

reviewText: When I first heard about a game, where you play as a writer trying to balance concerns for his family against the demands of his deadlines I was intrigued, but not quite enough for the price tag. I'm glad I waited for a sale, because I find the game very mediocre. The most serious problem is that the very simplistic gameplay elementels don't suit the narrative structure that is the game's main selling point. Basically it a single level repetitive 1st person stealth game. You are a ghost that must remain unseen, explore the house in which the Kaplan family of three lives, read their thoughts and letters. Then brain wash the titular novelist in his sleep so that he will make the decision you find most appropriate.\nIf that hasn't deterred you from trying out the game I'd advise you to wait for a sale to grab it. It's can be completed in 1½-2 hours or much less you disable stealth and don't explore each chapter. It can be longer if you wish to replay it. But I don't find it interesting enough for a replay. There are better story driven games out there, stronger in both narrative, emotional depth and gameplay, even all at once, whereas this game is pretty lackluster in all these aspects.
An emotional journey.
Amazing story, solid gameplay even though it begins to repeat slightly towards the end. Good way to spend an hour and a half, and definatly replayable.

You are an haunt in a house occupied for the summer by a dysfunctional family - a depressive, alcohol-prone father, a mother who gave up her painting career for family and a son that utterly ignores her, fixated as he it on the fatherly figure whose attention he so much craves that his happiness entirely depends on him.

What the game does brilliantly is to remind us, the players, of the tragedy of familiar life, in which the parent's goals could be fulfilled, or at least compromised, if not for the children throwing numerous wrenches in the works. The message is apparently clear: if you want to fulfill your dreams, your descendents won't be heppy, and if you make them happy, you will have failed at your path, ensuring they will fail at theirs when their time as parents come in an eternal cycle of self-denial.

Or not :) What remains is that you, the player/presence, whose actions touch so many, seen from time to time creeping right behind someone loved, whose presence is felt thoughout history and with the power to change the minds of the occupiers, you will still be alone and hiding, never really living a story of your own - not until you get out of the house.

The Novelist has a very intriguing premise, interesting game design, and decent replayability. You are actually given the freedom to compromise on tough decisions that most other games lack. There's enough variability that any two people who play this game are going to get different endings AND different experiences in getting there. As an added bonus, almost every decision is difficult. Your marriage is faultering right off the bat, your son is already struggling in school, and you're going to go broke if you don't do well with your novel. Every single decision matters, and the impacts are felt in the way the characters behave the rest of the game. When you fail you will feel it, even if you you were just trying to make the best possible decision at the time.\nUnfortunatly the actual game mechanics simply aren't fun. As a ghost that can jump from different light sources your movements are slow, interactivity is sparse, and the process of finding clues and memories is repetitive. The house is the only level in the game, and while there are changes to it based on past decisions oftentimes 'gameplay' winds up just being checking the same spots every day. Some rooms are so rarely utilized they just kind of sit there as window dressing. Few if any clues are genuinly hidden so there's no real sense of discovery in searching for them again. As interested as I am in trying different decisions and seeing different outcomes I really don't feel like slogging through the gameplay again to get to them.\nStill, the core concept works. As repetitive as the gameplay itself may be the decision making always feels like it matters and the game fulfills its promise in making sure it DOES matter, creating an emotional and personal connection beyond what most games can achieve. I'd still recommend the game, despite my qualms.

Charming little game. Very absorbing. I enjoyed watching their lives unfold and having a hand in the decisions they make. I ended up getting a very pleasing result to all the decisions, which I was very proud of considering that none of the choices were easy, because you want fulfill all their desires in each chapter. For those who don't want to spend all their time twitch" shooting everything that moves in the face

reviewText: The Novelist is one of those games that helps you think more than you should not about the mechanics but about the decisions you make. In the game you play a ghost who tries to reconcile the issues of the familiy evenly and in hopes that they end up all well. I found myself thinking at the end of the game why i chose to neglect the child so much and whether that reflects my personal priorities in life. Overall The Novelist is a great game that i recommend.

The Novelist is an original and refreshing idea in storytelling slightly imperfectly executed, but still well worth playing. Coming out of the gate, it's an exhilarating storytelling experience that really gets you engage in the game. The chief issue is that the further you play, the more repetetive and almost rote the gameplay becomes. Add to that some fairly contrived-seeming conflicts of choice, and it falls a little short of the mark that it sets at its outset. However, that mark is so high that what you get instead is still a really worthwhile experience. Part of me wants to replay the game and see what different choices result in, but there's no way to do that quickly, so I'll have to wait until there's more time. I won't be surprised if I do some day return to it, though. If you have any interest at all in unique gameplay and game-based storytelling on a personal level (dealing with ordinary people's lives rather than having to guide the Chosen One to defeat the Emperor of All Evil), then you owe it to yourself to play this game.
The Novelist is a game where you need patient, and for the first time you are the one who scares. I both it as a hunch and believe me was the best hunch ever!

reviewText:
This game is an interactive story, the time played on my account (2 hours at time of writing) was enough to run through the game once on it's 'stealth' difficulty (i.e. with some 'game' elements) without missing any compromises, so if you are expecting a long game this is not it.

What this game does provide is a very interesting story about a struggling writer and his family and how the choices they make (or you make for them) as a family can have lasting effects on their lives.

People who dislike fiction or find it hard to empathise with a character will want to avoid The Novelist, but if you are willing to engage the characters emotionally then you will find yourself faced with difficult choices about who to help and who to dissapoint and I was often left feeling guilty about my decision to go with one over another, wondering if I had made the right choice as the descriptive scenes outlined the consequences of my decision.

The game appears to have a great deal of replayability in that there are multiple choices to be made along the way, but as someone who tends to go with the decision that feels 'right' I imagine my playthroughs would all end with the same outcome!

Overall this is a very good piece of interactive fiction with minimal gameplay elements (hide and seek), recommended for people who enjoy the characters in a story more than the action and seeing the consequences of decisions playing out and changing them for better and worse.

Overall, this felt just far too contrived for me to ever really connect to. A huge part of it is that it's tough to link to the sympathy of the character difficulties because its all based on what is, ultimately, feeling like some sort of rich/upper-class background where the choices center around one character a professional writer, one character wanting to be a professional artist, and the needs of their kid. The choices that have to get made at that point just start to feel ridiculous. Each week there's multiple days off, they're traveling to have a summer 'off' working, and so to be in that situation and still not being able to manage compromises like read to the kid and work" just feels ridiculously absurd to me.\n\nBeyond that

reviewText: As others have said, this game felt a bit bland. You spend the entire time in the house and it begins to just become repetitive. This game gives you a chance to train at life" :)

In this title the player is a ghost who walks around at a snails pace or possesses light fixtures to do nothing. You are haunting the cabin of the blandest family possible. There is hardly any characterization or interaction in this story driven game. Your objective is to fufill the desires of one single person either the writer, the mother or the child. Once there desire is fufilled, it is revealed that the lives of the other two family members will take a negative turn; though it doesn't really matter to the player because of how generic each character is. Everyone is devoid of any personality whatsoever. The writer just mopes around never really writing a book the whole time he just fiddles around with an outline that isn't even finished. The mother paints unimpressive scenery. The child only scribbles crayon drawings of his father with himself either to the left or to the right of his father.

On the subject of interaction, there really is not any between the player and the world or for that fact the non playable characters and each other. Every character avoids everyone in the immediate area to the point that they have developed this anti social habit of leaving notes all over the cabin to communicate with eachother.

Gameplay consists of reading enough notes so you can use your ghost powers to read a persons mind so you can find a physical object. Once you find that object you finish the quest by entering a characters bedroom at night and whispering boring suggestions into there ears to influence them into living life in a predetermined way.

Graphics are horrible. They remind me of this unfinished free game called Facade" which is a much better game in every regard to "the novelist" and pretty much is the exact same type of game. The only difference is that Facade actually lets you interact with everything in the area and not only is there consequences for the NPC's but for the player as well. Which makes it a fun replayable game unlike the novelist.

Bottom line The Novelist is recommended for people who want to buy gifts for people they hate.

Recommendations for people who want an actual game with a proper story and game play; "To The Moon" it's like a 16 bit RPG with puzzles instead of random turn based battles."

The game may get repetitive at time, but the choice and consequences you make don't. I found that I could relate really well with the story and at times made me tear up at the compromises.\n\nFeels simulator 9000 10/10 would feel again.

The Novelist tells a compelling story about a man torn between priorities.  Sadly, the game that carries this story is dull, repetitive, and mechanically simple.

Dan Kaplan is a writer who has taken his family on vacation in the hopes that the experience will allow him to overcome writers block.  Oh, and he also needs to save his marriage and connect with his son.  Some vacation!

While the game never outright explains what you're playing as, the best label I can slap onto your role is 'Ghost'.  Besides traditional first person movement, you can possess lights, make them flicker, and seamlessly move from one light to another via a direct sight-line (similar to the security cameras in Watch_Dogs).  The Kaplans will get spooked if they see you, so you have to spend a lot of time hiding in the light fixtures.

This adds some very interesting stealth gameplay... provided you don't wuss out and pick the 'Story Mode', which renders you completely invisible to the Kaplans.  It's completely unnecessary, since I never once got spotted during my play-through.  The game does try to ramp up the difficulty a little by having some lights turned off in the later game, preventing you from using them and forcing you to actually foot it between certain rooms.  It's more of a minor annoyance than a major game changer, however.

The actual meat of the game involves you using your ghostly powers to guide choices made by Dan in regards to both working on his novel and spending time with his family.  Each chapter starts with a brief plot point, followed by you exploring the house for clues related to what each family member has on their mind.  The clues often take the shape of diaries, notes, drawings, letters...

Would now be a bad time to point out that developer Kent Hudson worked on Bioshock 2?

You also have to collect memories from characters.  Doing so requires you to get into their heads, which you do by getting sneaking up and possessing them.  Once inside, you explore... the exact same house, except now you don't have to worry about getting spotted while looking for yet more clues (now in the form of the actual characters, frozen in time).

Once you acquire all the clues and memories related to a character, you'll find out what they want, and can then complete the chapter by finding a specified object and whispering a suggestion into Dans ear while he sleeps.  If you're a real keener (and managed to avoid spooking them), you can find out what one or both of the other characters want, which will give you the option of reaching a compromise.  This allows you to satisfy two characters, while only leaving one disappointed.

The entire process starts to become routine by the third act.  You evade detection, collect clues, search for memories, and then make a choice.  Repeat for each of the nine chapters.  You can always rely on clues being concentrated in the same few rooms, often on the same desks and tables, so you never have to look too hard.  By the seventh act I was just looking forward to the game ending.  Not a good sign.

Wait a second...

Majority of gameplay is reading diaries and letters.
Former Bioshock 2 developer.

This is Gone Home, but with actual gameplay!  I guess hat's enough for a 5 out of 10.

This is a game that I am going to give a very soft recommendation for, because while this game has plenty of faults, I still enjoyed playing through it and I think others would too.

At it's core, The Novelist is a game about interpersonal conflict and the moral and ethical struggles that comes with trying to balance the wants and needs of individuals in a family. Each chapter in the game presents the player with three desires, one for each member of the family, and you are asked to make a decision based on these desires. I personally enjoyed exploring the house to find all the clues to each family member and I also enjoyed going through their memories to learn more about the situation as well.

However there are several problems I have with The Novelist, the chief one being that the story in and of itself isn't that interesting. It's a typical story, Dad wants to work on his novel, Mom wants to save the marriage and get back into a profession she had to give up when the kid arrived, and the kid wants to play with Dad and is struggling in school and is bullied. We've all seen stories that use these elements elsewhere, and they used them a lot better there. Another issue I had was that the individual chapters didn't seem to be all that connected. Each chapter felt more like variations of the same 3 or 4 issues and the decisions made in the previous chapter seemed to have little influence in other chapters.

This game has some flaws. Maybe, the gameplay is a bit redundant and overall repetitive. The graphics are rather simple (not ugly, simple!) and there is a low density of details. True.
On the other side there is a game that is pretty heart shacking and intellectual challenging. The game is basic, but that has its meaning because it focuses you on the story, the characters, the development and, most of all, your decision!
This game is simple, but it is maybe the game where your decisions have the greatest impact on the development of the story. Therefore, not only “the novelist” is not “not a game” – it pushes the idea of controlling the story, not only its outcome, in a progressive direction.
That this can’t be without flaws in the performance. But a game doesn’t have to be perfectly save, to be good. Any experiment has its mixed outcomes.

And therefor, “The Novelist” should be played because of its great outcome AND because of its flaws.

I guess this is just not my cup of tea.\nThe game os more based on observation. It is not that challenging and the story is not that brilliant to keep you engaged.\nIf you read a lot of books, and prefer to think, and not only observe I can't recomend this to you.
Equally depressing and joyful.

This game, seemingly based somewhat on Woolf's novel 'To the Lighthouse,' was a marvelous experience. While it is heavily story based and has multiple endings, it DOES have gameplay, unlike some of the Indie walking simulators that you find. However, you'd have to be really silly to actually get punished for failing to do a good job with the gameplay, I feel. Still, it's enough to keep you actually playing the game while watching the story unravel according to your actions.\nThe game highlights some of the same existencial issues that 'To the Lighthouse' does: it highlights family and relationship issues in day-to-day living, and the problems balancing work with the two. It also shows that the lives of all people invovled are transient and fleeting, and all that's left of us afterwards is our art: whether it be the books we write or the paintings we craft. The shared symbol of the lighthouse and some of the shared activities of both families gives them both the same ambiance, I felt.\nRegardless, definitely look into this one, as it leaves you something to learn and ponder about your own life.
This was a good game. It was a nice change from the normal. It's the relax, have a drink and enjoy type of game. It is short but still spot on.

Its a simple game, but with a great story. You are like story maker. You have to choose, who you will help or hang out in the family. It gives you a diffrent ending, For indie game, It is a master piece.

It's an interesting game... Exploritory in nature without being overly complicated or convoluted. A different approach to telling a story, and it gets an A" in my book for simply being different. Otherwise though

reviewText:
The Novelist is one of the greastest game storytelling games out there. You won't find another diamond like this one.

Pros:
1) The story and theme are crafted to perfection. Everything makes logical sense. The characters are simple to understand and grasp. You're intrigued at every time whether it's by curiousity, suspense, hard choices, and/or personal reactions to the result. There are backstories that don't affect the main one which increase morals taught and entertainment. I personally joyed over the latter effect obviously. To avoid spoilers, I won't go further.
2) The graphics are great and there is no lag. Even though the game itself is more important than graphics, this can be a good plus.
3) The controls feel comfortable and reasonable.
4) Anyone who aided in making this creation seemed well credited especially advisors and programs.

Cons (Sorta?):
1) The stealth may feel repetitious if you're not interested into the story, but I must say it's a bit fun, and it makes sense when the video game is based more on story than sneaking; otherwise, it wouldn't have been as great. A harder challenge feels worse with a terrible reward.
2) It involved a lot of reading, but I definitely enjoyed myself when the pace was mixed with stealth.

Overall, I have no regrets. If you want to hear an excellent story while pacing the reading with sneaking, buy this game. In the case that you are purely looking for a stealth game challenge, then I would reconsider. I hope the dev continues making games as great as this one, and even if he didn't, at least he created The Novelist.

If you liked To the moon" this will be right up your alley. The gameplay can get quite repetitive but the emotional impact of the story and the choices you make more than makes up for that.\n\nOverall a very enjoyable and thought provoking game."

This is an extremely laid back yet engaging game. It does everything it promises in the blurb, it tells a short, engaging story about a family in crisis. You guide them through it and your decisions will effect them for better or for worse.\nWhile it is a simple enough premise the execution is extremely well done and you really do care about the different people in this story and the choices will sometimes be agonising.\nIf you like narrative driven video games The Novelist is a great choice.

I enjoyed the concept and the artwork of this game, however I did find myself bored at times. Once I figured out the general strategy of the game, which as a casual gamer, I didn't feel was very challenging, there wasn't much more to it. I didn't feel that the story was striking enough to keep me engaged by the script content alone. I don't think I'd be happy paying more then $5 for The Novelist, but I do think it was a very good introduction to interesting and original work in gaming. I hope to see more from Orthogonal Games!\nI recommend buying this game if you can get it during a Steam sale.

reviewText:
The premise of this game is great and I couldn't wait to try it out. It succeeds in the sense that I found the conceit interesting (you're essentially a spirit, possessing objects and rifling through the family's things for clues about their goals in life), and it was fun to play through in a single sitting. I enjoyed the compromise system because it added a little weight to the game that otherwise would have been too simple.

That said the constrains of the gameplay system made it difficult for me to relate to the Kaplan family. Unfortunately it ended up making them all a bit unsympathetic. For example, I would think in a real family when the mother's relative passes away unexpectedly, your child wouldn't respond to a change in plans with a screaming and crying fit, especially not at ten years old. Also I didn't understand why Mom and Child couldn't leave Dad alone until his novel was done. The deadline is set and it will be a finite project, so stop asking him to play and all that until he's done! Or when you have the option of taking the kid to a fair, the mom on a trail hike, or dad to a campfire. The mom goes on the hike if you don't compromise with her, but she twists her ankle and isn't able to complete it. This makes her angry. It just felt way too codependent to me then, like go on the hike by yourself and enjoy it! Lastly, Dan giving up on writing after that just makes me feel like he wasn't serious enough about it in the first place.

Still a fun and interesting adventure remeniscient of the Stanley Parable but played much straighter.
This is one of the most original games I have played in a very long time. Thank you so much for allowing us to share in this adventure.

Somewhat quick and pretty heartwrenching, The Novelist is a game all about choices and juggling way too many things.

You don't play as Dan, the Novelist in question, but as a benevolent spirit possessing the house whispering things to its patrons. Most of the gameplay is just going from lamp to lamp, going around the house without being spotted, though there's also an option to turn it off and just play for the story. Either works fine though you might want to have it off as while the stealth mechanic is immersive, it's mostly a way of keeping it more interactive which is weak enough already. It lives in an interesting fashion in this way.

The story itself is much stronger as you have to make small decisions which will help Dan with his writing career, keep his marriage together, and put some time aside for their son as well. If you spend time learning about the whole story you can make some good decisions, though more often than not you'll have to make painful compromises leaving few happy though proper planning and reaction can bring a happy ending for all three members of the family. I didn't, but I got close. All the while rather sad atmospheric piano music plays in the background making everything a lot harder than it needs to be. Oh, and every playthrough randomizes the different events that occur in the household which livens things up a bit.

So overall it's a good interesting engrossing yet short game. If you feel on the ropes about it you should probably wait for a sale. Otherwise it's definately worth a play/read.

This game is one of those cozy little indie games that you play once, and then talk about with all of your other hipster gaming friends, who like to think that they're  getting more than just entertainment out of their gaming habits.

Joke aside, the game is fairly different and unique, and features a well written story and good voice acting.

It has two game-modes, but they're identical apart from offering some additional difficulty, but I found that the stealth difficulty was actually not very interesting. On the other hand, the story difficulty has no difficulty at all, and it feels like the game is missing a component, so I recommend that people choose the stealth difficulty.

The game is very similar to games like Gone Home (well, to be honest, I suppose these two games sort of form a genre, as I can't think of any other games like these).

The game tells a story. You can slightly affect the story, but the actual gameplay is simply to explore the story.

Unlike in gone home, you have some influence in this game, and need to make some decisions. What decisions you can make is based on what clues you've discovered, and whether or not you were spotted.

If you're bored a weekend, and need something to relax with, this is a great buy for that. Anyone can play and enjoy this.
Very interesting game, difficult choices every chapter.\n\nI wonder who 'I' was though. In the game, possessing lights and all that.

This game has some flaws. Maybe, the gameplay is a bit redundant and overall repetitive. The graphics are rather simple (not ugly, simple!) and there is a low density of details. True.
On the other side there is a game that is pretty heart shacking and intellectual challenging. The game is basic, but that has its meaning because it focuses you on the story, the characters, the development and, most of all, your decision!
This game is simple, but it is maybe the game where your decisions have the greatest impact on the development of the story. Therefore, not only “the novelist” is not “not a game” – it pushes the idea of controlling the story, not only its outcome, in a progressive direction.
That this can’t be without flaws in the performance. But a game doesn’t have to be perfectly save, to be good. Any experiment has its mixed outcomes.

And therefor, “The Novelist” should be played because of its great outcome AND because of its flaws.

Like most games it has its good points as well as bad points, and this is all opinion based.

The story is rather simple, predictable, and sometimes does not make much sense; the graphics are pretty sterile too. I found some of the characters (mostly the wife so far) to be faulted to the point where I kinda wanted as a ghost to come down and slap them a bit. But, I found the idea of playing  helpful ghost very unique and interesting. And it shows a glimpse into some of the pressures a professional writer can have (the idea that yes i am home, no i can't devote the entirety of my time to you i do have to work). The game is very atmospheric with a slow almost sad tone to everything from the voices to the music.

unfortunately for me because of that sad atmosphere I can't play much. If you suffer from depression I'd recommend caution with the game, but otherwise its refreshing and enjoyable.

reviewText:
The game's minimalist art stole my heart from the moment I saw it. Not only is it easy on the computer- its simply wonderous on your eyes. The entire concept behind the game is uniqe and refreshing. I'm rather tired of shooting zombies, nazis, or aliens.
The ambiguity within the game makes the story entirely your own, which is beautiful. The characters are relatable- and I felt actual disappointment when I wasn't able to make all of them happy. It also told me quite a lot about who I was as a person and where my priorities lie. I can honestly say that a game has never done that for me since Shadow of the Colossus. I honestly don't want to replay the game with different choices- not because it was bad but because it would ruin my immersion.
The game is overall beautiful, memorable, and fun.
I don't have a lot of bad things to say about it- if anything at all other than that I was sad it was so short. Of course, it has a lot of replay value and I understand its shortness it not being a triple A title.
I give it a 9.5/10 and highly recommend it for people who are looking for a more artistic and story-driven game.

I went in thinking it would be just another choice after choice and nothing happens, but this game will send chills down your spine with the soundtrack and the facts. It may seem like a fictional ghost story but this game is more than real. 7/10. Doing another run for sure.

The bad

If there's one thing I've learned in adulthood, it's that free time is the most precious limited resource we have. The decision to do anything in life is at the expense of countless other potential activities, which is the fundamental struggle I deal with while playing video games all the time. Where will you invest your free time? Your writer's block? Your broken marriage? Your needy son? You can't do it all.

The Novelist is a game about family, priorities, and compromise.

Perhaps the game's most brilliant coup is casting you in the role of a ghost. It would be easy and incorrect to assume that the player character is the novelist himself. You, the ghost, work behind the scenes as an observer of the experience and can only help to influence the thoughts of the novelist. You the Player decide where he invests his time, and that decision (made at the end of each chapter by whispering suggestions into his ear while he sleeps) affects his wife, his son, and his career.

Why is this so brilliant? It's a question of agency. If you controlled the novelist directly, you might get frustrated by the family's inability to communicate successfully. In fact, you might feel that frustration anyway, since each character begins the game with wildly different needs. Aren't I working on my career for the sake of my family?" you might ask yourself as the novelist. "Can't my family accept that a few months to myself will pay off in the long term?" "Why can't I make compromises that please everybody?" "Why can't my wife and son spend time together without me?" These are all valid questions....but you are not the novelist. You are just a ghost. This is the rare game where your limitations as a player work within the context of your character
date: and your limited and indirect effect on the game world makes total sense.\n\nIn the end
recommended: while you can only set the stage and watch it unfold
hoursPlayed: the way the game makes you think remains powerfully human. How do I take care of my family? How do I balance my goals and their needs?\n\nWhat will make me a happy person?"

reviewText: I thought it was a great game, it works on a very deep psychological level as you are faced with making some difficult and uncomfortable decisions and facing their consequences. I really haven't played anything else like this. The game is short and simple yes, but there is a lot of replay value as you try to find the best outcomes for all the characters. You may even find that it turns a mirror on you and makes you consider more deeply the effects that your own decisions have on those around you in real life.

This game is so much fun. Not shoot-em-up, action-based fun but think-about-your-choice-and-how-it-affects-the-characters fun. At the beginning of the game you're given a central conflict that needs to be resolved. On each level of the gameplay you see the conflict from three different points of view - the dad, the mom and the son. You are then tasked with making a decision for one of the characters based on the information you're given in that level. Your decision affects all the characters either negatively or positively. By the end you really start to feel for each of these characters. Wonderfully written and often heartbreaking.

In The Novelist, you play as a ghost in a house where the Kaplan family has come for a summer vacation. The husband is the titular novelist, the wife is attempting to get back into painting and their young son  has a slight learning disability . Both the child and wife wish to have more family time (amongst other things), whereas the dad is under pressure to complete his current novel in an attempt to meet deadlines. There are also many other events that happen (all narrated via text or background image+text) but I won't go into those to avoid spoilers.

The basic gameplay is fairly simple:
Teleporting from one active lamp to another (stealth) in your field of view. This is disabled is the difficulty mode called Story. You are suggested to be stealthy so that you have increased story options.
Going into people's memories to encounter small clues" regarding what the character wants.
Investigate different objects in the household such as reading notes
date: diary entries and seeing drawings made by the little boy.\nMaking choices regarding whose desired outcome should play out (the husband's
recommended: wife's or child's). There is also an additional option for compromise on one of these outcomes (I think this is not available if you are seen by the family member
hoursPlayed: but I'm not too sure because I was never detected). The compromise is not always a positive thing
voteText: so it feels like a different option not just a second desirable outcome that makes one more family member happy.\nAt night--when everybody is asleep--you can explore the house for clues related to it's past. This is always in the form of diaries or notes that glow.\nWhat I liked: The story choices have some genuine emotional impact

A Paladin's Steam Review: The Novelist. Story Cliches and Unlikable Characters Abound.Genre: 1st Person Exploration Narrative Game.
Developed & Published by: Orthogonal Games
Platform: Windows, Mac, Linux
Business Model: Base Game.
Copy Purchased by Myself Preamble
While this particular title dodged my radar last year, I gave it a try this year after seeing a review of it and being intrigued by it. Controlling a ghost following around a family and giving them directions on their life seemed like a pretty good idea for a videogame to explore. But was the execution solid? Read on.

Overall Gameplay
Each day is repetitive stream of the same tasks with slightly different flavor text. (Gather clues about what’s bothering each family member, see their memories then choose which solution you think is best all while avoiding being detected). The stealth is basic and is more a chore than fun as you just jump from light fixture to other light fixture, getting out of them only briefly to read some more text. The game even lets you turn the need for stealth off which I would recommend doing, if the story itself was more interesting.

My main problem with the story is that it uses way too many cliches with too many forced emotional scenes. To the point of finding myself detesting the game the longer I played it. There are choices that get way too unrealistic. There’s one part where a grandmother dies and the Novelist has to make the choice to either go to a book signing or go to the funeral to support his wife. The company he works for claims they can’t reschedule the book signing and that it would be very bad for him to miss it. I...I have a really hard time believing that they couldn't reschedule it due to a family member’s death. Even if I could buy that being a real situation, there’s another example that I found downright silly. It boils down to: Wife wants to camp far away and Son wants to camp close by. And if you don’t choose correctly, someone’s unhappy. What?! That’s like whining about getting two chocolate cookies instead of three. It feels like it was put in just to get an emotional reaction where all I could think is: “these are some real narcissistic people”.

Character flaws
Which is then followed by the worst problem this game has: we don’t have well fleshed out characters here. They are nothing but cliches. Despite spending quite a few intimate hours with them, I didn’t get any real connection with them.  There’s a writer who’s suffering from writer’s block. There’s a mother who wants to be an artist again. There’s a son being a generic kid. That’s all I remember about them. I will admit, that having cliche characters for us to project ourselves onto them may have been intentional game design. But I find it to be the experience to be less for it.

PC Settings
Most of the PC settings are there. You’ve got resolution, AA, V-Sync, subtitles, difficulty and voiceover reading if wanted. Graphically, the game isn’t all that impressive. It’s a weird pseudo CGI/Realistic style that is somehow lacking in detail. If it’s intentional, I’m not a fan of it. The soundtrack is a “depressing” solo piano that tries to bring emotional oomph to the game. However, it falls into the cliche area of soundtrack design and comes off as extremely flat when I played it. The game’s coding is solid, there weren’t any bugs, errors or crashes during my playthrough.

Final Thoughts
I have a hard time recommending this game. I’ve already hammered on the story quite a bit but I didn’t dig the cliche story, the cliche characters and I definitely hated the forced emotional moments caused by no-win choices by overly narcissistic characters. If you’re in a similar situation to the Novelist (struggling artist with a family), the game might speak to you and you might get something out of it. Otherwise, I’d look elsewhere.

reviewText:
The Novelist is a story-based game that sees the player take on the role of a ghostly character, assisting the Kaplans, Dan, his wife and his son, in their decisions over the course of a summer break. Gameplay-wise this means finding letters and memories to find out what each family member wants and then finding a specific item in order to fulfil that want. However, you can only please one person each time, compromising with one other which results in there always being a third that doesn’t get their wish. Unfortunately, in terms of gameplay, this becomes very repetitive, quickly turning into a hidden object style game. Where the game hooks you though is from the responses of your actions from each character. Each action’s consequence can be felt emotionally from them and a connection between them and the player is formed. As this is seemingly a rather rare occurrence within the medium, this was a delightful thing to happen. Hopefully future videogames can draw on this and help to create more connections between their players and the characters in their game.

The small scale of the story and the before-mentioned repetitive gameplay will put many off, but for those that can look past those points then there is something worth experiencing here.

The Novelist is an original and refreshing idea in storytelling slightly imperfectly executed, but still well worth playing. Coming out of the gate, it's an exhilarating storytelling experience that really gets you engage in the game. The chief issue is that the further you play, the more repetetive and almost rote the gameplay becomes. Add to that some fairly contrived-seeming conflicts of choice, and it falls a little short of the mark that it sets at its outset. However, that mark is so high that what you get instead is still a really worthwhile experience. Part of me wants to replay the game and see what different choices result in, but there's no way to do that quickly, so I'll have to wait until there's more time. I won't be surprised if I do some day return to it, though. If you have any interest at all in unique gameplay and game-based storytelling on a personal level (dealing with ordinary people's lives rather than having to guide the Chosen One to defeat the Emperor of All Evil), then you owe it to yourself to play this game.

I voted for this game to be Greenlit and was happy to see that it has mostly lived up to the potential it showed then. You play some sort of ghost or spirit that inhabits a house which a writer named Dan and his wife and son rent for the summer so that Dan can focus on working on his next book.  The game is divided into several chapters as the spirit you have to move throughout the house reading letters, reading the family members thoughts and exploring their memories to find out the desires of each family member. You do all this while trying to remain undetected (though if you want to focus on the story you can turn the requirement for stealth off).

When you've uncovered each family members desire you have to pick one and whisper it to Dan so it is acted upon. The family member who's desire you picked will be happy but the other two will not. At the end of the chapter after you've made your choice you get to see the outcomes on each character and it is quite difficult to see the negative outcomes as you do end up feeling sorry for them. It's a pity the game doesn't have more solutions that would satisfy more than one character so your decision can become an agonizing choice.

The real strength of this game is the story it weaves about the family. You get to know each character and how they feel through their memories and the letters you read and while the story this game tells about them is the typical trials and tribulations of a family, it's done so well that you do end up caring about them and that makes the choices you make that bit more agonizing.

The only downside of this game is that the exploration side where you move about the house trying to find letters and look through the families memories gets boring after a short while as it gets repetitive doing more less the same thing in every chapter.

Overall though this is a great story based games that will please people who enjoyed games like Gone Home and Dear Esther. It's a 7/10 from me.

The designer for this game left his job working with huge teams to make an entire game by himself, and it shows. I'm glad I bought the game because I have hope that the money he's made with this game will lead to something worth playing in the future, but this ain't it.

The script gives the illusion of choice, but you're following a narrow path with gameplay that is little more than hide and seek. I bought the game hoping for a compelling storyline, but it rarely reached beyond evenly distributing attention into three buckets, with a unsatisfyingly easy end.

The whole game is half an hour long with no reply value. Buy the game, download it for an afternoon, then save the room on your computer content that you just donated money to a good cause.

A great balancing act between one's dreams and obligations. True to life, the conflicts that arise between a man and his family cause a sense of gravity and depth for every decision and, more importantly, omission.

I personally recommend playing in Story mode before trying stealth" mode. That way you can soak yourself in the narrative and not worry about being stealthy.

Highly recommended for people who are drawn to narrative driven games like Stanley Parable
recommended: The Walking Dead and Dear Esther."

reviewText: A game that gets to the heart of what it means to be a good person.  It's a question I've wrestled with my entire life.  There is a line-- somewhere, for everyone-- that has to be drawn.  When do you stop helping other people and start helping yourself?  You can always be helping other people.  You could be doing it right now, but you're not.  You're reading this.  To find a game that forces you to make those decisions is both welcoming and painful.  I played it straight through, and I won't tell you the ending I received, but it's probably obvious.  I would imagine that Jesus had to take time for himself.  I would imagine Jesus wanted to escape from everything and be alone his entire life because it decreases the obligation and the guilt that goes along with not helping others.  But he kept helping.  And died for it.  I guess there's a quiet beauty in that.

Absolutely brilliant. Love it.\n\nI'm not sure it's a game, as such, but exploring the lives of Dan, his wife and his kid and then making the hard decisions to influence their lives is really engaging.

It's an interesting concept, but I didn't find it very fun to play. It's certainly not a game you go to after a hard day.

Chapters get repetitive and waiting for the family members to move out of the way quickly gets boring as well. Neither the story nor the graphics were captivating enough to make me play it again and see other endings of the story.

Playing early versions of Kent Hudson’s The Novelist excited me over the potential. When it came out, it had exceeded all my expectations. Balancing decisions and making compromises with your career and relationships with your wife and son is very difficult. Often you’ll go into a chapter feeling like Dan absolutely needs to spend more time in one area of life and something happens that makes that decision much harder to make. I’m totally in love with the randomizations and natural unbalance the game presents. Nine chapters in a random order, three potential choices, even the music throughout the game is randomly generated. The Novelist is brilliant.

I wouldn't call this a game -- it's not even a Visual Novel.  The Novelist has simlarities to Gone Home and To The Moon in that on the surface it appears to be a game, but it's really not.  Real life is never as simple as the binary choices the user is expected to make in this plot and many people will feel quite frustrated and disatisfied with the limited possibilities.  That being said, I still enjoyed it.  I for one had mostly forgotten about what it was like to be a 6 year old child, and this narrative provided interesting insight.\n\nIf you are looking for short diversion that will tug at your heartstrings, check it out.

This game is a wonderful depiction of the everyday struggle of balancing a family. The decisions I made in this game not only revealed the Kaplans' lives, but also  a little about myself. I was in tears by the end. And if you're a family person, you will be too.

Another interesting indie game.

It is short -- about 1 1/2 hours per playthrough, but it lends itself to multiple playthroughs.

The game is about choice -- when there are three characters with three different goals (a husband with his career, a wife and her career, and a son with difficulties in school), what is the right choice to make? Often the answer is complex, and there is no right answer. Give up to much for your family, and you might end up resenting your family.

I recommend, if you are into the indie/story based plots, or interested in how choice can be done in video games. Compare the choices/outcomes in this game with Fallout, Mass Effect, and Walking Dead.
One of the best video game stories I've played in a while.  Highly recommended.
This game is good, has an awesome story line. I like the simpleness of it, I also like the fact that it is different then most other games. Thank you.

This game for 15 dollars? No. I finished this game in 80 minutes. The story is so short and there isn't really any depth to the choices. I literally knew the consequences of each action and knew it wouldn't make any strony collateral damage in the ending. For example and this may be a spoiler: I gave no strong attention to the novelist and in the end he still got the letter that forces his family to move if I choose. The consequences draw up only to the end of each chapter, making the story feel stupid. The area is restricted to one tiny house with little objects. The game is very limited and a predictable story about marriage problems and work. Want a heartwarming story about family? Go talk to your parents or kids or the guy or girl you like.

This game make you question your morals when it comes to family and career. If you treat this like a game, you lose some of the power. Rather, it is better to treat the characters as people, thus making the decisions you make seem more important. What are you willing to sacrifice of compromise? How will this affect the things you love?
Very interesting game, difficult choices every chapter.\n\nI wonder who 'I' was though. In the game, possessing lights and all that.

The Novelist tells a compelling story about a man torn between priorities.  Sadly, the game that carries this story is dull, repetitive, and mechanically simple.

Dan Kaplan is a writer who has taken his family on vacation in the hopes that the experience will allow him to overcome writers block.  Oh, and he also needs to save his marriage and connect with his son.  Some vacation!

While the game never outright explains what you're playing as, the best label I can slap onto your role is 'Ghost'.  Besides traditional first person movement, you can possess lights, make them flicker, and seamlessly move from one light to another via a direct sight-line (similar to the security cameras in Watch_Dogs).  The Kaplans will get spooked if they see you, so you have to spend a lot of time hiding in the light fixtures.

This adds some very interesting stealth gameplay... provided you don't wuss out and pick the 'Story Mode', which renders you completely invisible to the Kaplans.  It's completely unnecessary, since I never once got spotted during my play-through.  The game does try to ramp up the difficulty a little by having some lights turned off in the later game, preventing you from using them and forcing you to actually foot it between certain rooms.  It's more of a minor annoyance than a major game changer, however.

The actual meat of the game involves you using your ghostly powers to guide choices made by Dan in regards to both working on his novel and spending time with his family.  Each chapter starts with a brief plot point, followed by you exploring the house for clues related to what each family member has on their mind.  The clues often take the shape of diaries, notes, drawings, letters...

Would now be a bad time to point out that developer Kent Hudson worked on Bioshock 2?

You also have to collect memories from characters.  Doing so requires you to get into their heads, which you do by getting sneaking up and possessing them.  Once inside, you explore... the exact same house, except now you don't have to worry about getting spotted while looking for yet more clues (now in the form of the actual characters, frozen in time).

Once you acquire all the clues and memories related to a character, you'll find out what they want, and can then complete the chapter by finding a specified object and whispering a suggestion into Dans ear while he sleeps.  If you're a real keener (and managed to avoid spooking them), you can find out what one or both of the other characters want, which will give you the option of reaching a compromise.  This allows you to satisfy two characters, while only leaving one disappointed.

The entire process starts to become routine by the third act.  You evade detection, collect clues, search for memories, and then make a choice.  Repeat for each of the nine chapters.  You can always rely on clues being concentrated in the same few rooms, often on the same desks and tables, so you never have to look too hard.  By the seventh act I was just looking forward to the game ending.  Not a good sign.

Wait a second...

Entire game takes place within a single house.
Majority of gameplay is reading diaries and letters.

This is Gone Home, but with actual gameplay!  I guess hat's enough for a 5 out of 10.

reviewText:
In The Novelist, you play as a ghost in a house where the Kaplan family has come for a summer vacation. The husband is the titular novelist, the wife is attempting to get back into painting and their young son  has a slight learning disability . Both the child and wife wish to have more family time (amongst other things), whereas the dad is under pressure to complete his current novel in an attempt to meet deadlines. There are also many other events that happen (all narrated via text or background image+text) but I won't go into those to avoid spoilers.

The basic gameplay is fairly simple:
Teleporting from one active lamp to another (stealth) in your field of view. This is disabled is the difficulty mode called Story. You are suggested to be stealthy so that you have increased story options.
Going into people's memories to encounter small clues" regarding what the character wants.
Investigate different objects in the household such as reading notes
date: diary entries and seeing drawings made by the little boy.\nMaking choices regarding whose desired outcome should play out (the husband's
recommended: wife's or child's). There is also an additional option for compromise on one of these outcomes (I think this is not available if you are seen by the family member
hoursPlayed: but I'm not too sure because I was never detected). The compromise is not always a positive thing
voteText: so it feels like a different option not just a second desirable outcome that makes one more family member happy.\nAt night--when everybody is asleep--you can explore the house for clues related to it's past. This is always in the form of diaries or notes that glow.\nWhat I liked: The story choices have some genuine emotional impact
helpfulPercent: at least for me. You may read some of the other reviews which do not agree with mne on this front.\nThe gameplay is simplistic without making small mistakes like too many collectibles

The Story mode difficulty option is a good choice if you want to introduce the game to a non-gamer.
What I misliked:
The characters do not have any real in-game chatter/conversations. This was a real bummer but I can understand why this decision was made; if you are in another room

While the shortness is explained in the context of the story (the house has cheap rent and few takers because of its past tenants' short stays)

Without that knowledge, I don't know if I could give this game a positive review, but I wouldn't give it a negative one. It was a good experience and well written story with a unique play style.

Overall, this felt just far too contrived for me to ever really connect to. A huge part of it is that it's tough to link to the sympathy of the character difficulties because its all based on what is, ultimately, feeling like some sort of rich/upper-class background where the choices center around one character a professional writer, one character wanting to be a professional artist, and the needs of their kid. The choices that have to get made at that point just start to feel ridiculous. Each week there's multiple days off, they're traveling to have a summer 'off' working, and so to be in that situation and still not being able to manage compromises like read to the kid and work" just feels ridiculously absurd to me.\n\nBeyond that

reviewText:
Somewhat quick and pretty heartwrenching, The Novelist is a game all about choices and juggling way too many things.

You don't play as Dan, the Novelist in question, but as a benevolent spirit possessing the house whispering things to its patrons. Most of the gameplay is just going from lamp to lamp, going around the house without being spotted, though there's also an option to turn it off and just play for the story. Either works fine though you might want to have it off as while the stealth mechanic is immersive, it's mostly a way of keeping it more interactive which is weak enough already. It lives in an interesting fashion in this way.

The story itself is much stronger as you have to make small decisions which will help Dan with his writing career, keep his marriage together, and put some time aside for their son as well. If you spend time learning about the whole story you can make some good decisions, though more often than not you'll have to make painful compromises leaving few happy though proper planning and reaction can bring a happy ending for all three members of the family. I didn't, but I got close. All the while rather sad atmospheric piano music plays in the background making everything a lot harder than it needs to be. Oh, and every playthrough randomizes the different events that occur in the household which livens things up a bit.

So overall it's a good interesting engrossing yet short game. If you feel on the ropes about it you should probably wait for a sale. Otherwise it's definately worth a play/read.

I just completed this game after a short 95 minute run. I would only buy this game if you want to play over and over for a different outcome. It was a waste of money if you play this only once. I went in thinking it would be just another choice after choice and nothing happens, but this game will send chills down your spine with the soundtrack and the facts. It may seem like a fictional ghost story but this game is more than real. 7/10. Doing another run for sure.
